channel.title: WSJ.com: Economy
channel.copyright: Copyright © Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All rights reserved.

item.title: What will capitalism in the U.S. look like in 50 years? We asked readers—and they had plenty of opinions
item.description: Wall Street Journal readers share their predictions.
item.dc:creator: Demetria Gallegos

item.title: The pay gap between women and men widened to 81 cents on the dollar by last year, the largest gap since 2016. Is the return to the office to blame?
item.description: Women have made big workforce gains, but their pay growth isn’t keeping pace with men’s.
item.dc:creator: Harriet Torry

item.title: Inflation isn’t as high as many economists expected earlier this year, but that’s not much comfort for Americans still flabbergasted at the prices of necessities like food, housing and insurance
item.description: The news that inflation could be worse is hardly comforting for millions of Americans still flabbergasted at the prices of necessities like food, housing and insurance.
item.dc:creator: Justin Lahart

item.title: Week Ahead for FX, Bonds: Fed Expected to Cut Rates; U.S.-China Talks Eyed
item.description: All eyes in the coming week will be on the U.S. Federal Reserve, which is widely expected to cut interest rates by another 25 basis points.
item.dc:creator: Dow Jones Newswires staff

item.title: Annual inflation heated up slightly in September, but not as much as economists expected, giving the Fed a clear path for widely expected rate cuts heading into their remaining meetings this year
item.description: The September data gives the Fed a clear path for widely expected rate cuts heading into their remaining meetings this year.
item.dc:creator: Harriet Torry

item.title: Consumer Sentiment Drops in October Michigan Survey
item.description: Stubborn inflation is weighing heavily on shoppers’ mood, according to the University of Michigan’s survey.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: U.S. And European Business Activity Pick Up in Continued Show Of Resilience
item.description: A rise in activity in the U.S., Europe and Asia indicates that the global economy remains resilient in the face of higher tariffs and greater uncertainty about relations between powerful countries.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: U.K. Retail Sales Rise for Fourth Straight Month
item.description: Retail sales volumes were unexpectedly higher in September, rising 0.5% on month, helped by tech stores and demand for gold.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: The U.S. is set to reopen an old trade dispute with China, upping the ante just days before President Trump and Chinese leader Xi Jinping are set to meet in South Korea
item.description: The move reopens an old trade dispute ahead of Trump’s meeting with China’s Xi Jinping.
item.dc:creator: Gavin Bade

item.title: Canada Retail Sales Pull Back After Rising 1% in August
item.description: Retail trade in Canada continues to be choppy, with retailers facing a pull back in sales last month that hints at spending uncertainty among consumers worried about job prospects, and fallout from a bruising trade dispute with the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Robb M. Stewart

item.title: Home sales rose in September to a seven-month high after buyers seized on declining mortgage rates
item.description: ​Sales r​eached a seven-month high, offering some hope that the housing market could be improving.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Friedman

item.title: Turkey’s Central Bank Slows Pace of Interest-Rate Cuts After Inflation Uptick
item.description: The Central Bank of Turkey cut its benchmark rate to 39.5% from 40.5%.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Bank of Korea Holds Rate Steady for Third Straight Time
item.description: South Korea’s central bank held its policy rate steady, reflecting caution over financial-stability risks and uncertainty over tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Kwanwoo Jun

item.title: Fed officials, who are unable to receive U.S. economic statistics due to the government shutdown, recently lost access to a separate measure of employment data from a third-party provider
item.description: Payroll processing firm ADP ended its data-sharing with the central bank after a speech highlighted the already-public collaboration.
item.dc:creator: Nick Timiraos

item.title: Indonesia’s Central Bank Surprises With Rate Hold
item.description: Indonesia’s central bank surprised markets by leaving interest rates on hold at its October meeting, pausing after three consecutive cuts as it keeps an eye on the rupiah.
item.dc:creator: Ying Xian Wong

item.title: PulteGroup Profit Falls as Housing Market Remains Stalled
item.description: PulteGroup recorded a lower third-quarter profit as affordability concerns continued to put off home buyers.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas G. Miller

item.title: U.S., Australia Deal Advances Critical Minerals Ambitions, While Detail Light
item.description: A new critical minerals deal between the U.S. and Australia sparked a rally in mining stocks.
item.dc:creator: Rhiannon Hoyle

item.title: China’s dominance of rare-earth minerals was decades in the making
item.description: Beijing used bare-knuckle tactics in a multidecade effort to consolidate control over supplies.
item.dc:creator: Jon Emont

item.title: Why one company is investing in rural America instead of offshoring jobs
item.description: Instead of offshoring, Provalus looks for small towns where incomes are low and people are eager for positions that will teach them 21st-century skills.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Weber

item.title: The number of unemployment claims filed by federal workers has grown sharply, reaching their highest level since a 34-day government shutdown that ended in January 2019
item.description: Data from states show that initial unemployment claims filed by federal government workers have jumped up this month.
item.dc:creator: Justin Lahart

item.title: Canada Existing-Home Sales Fall in September
item.description: Existing-home sales in Canada declined in September from the previous month, and prices fell to their lowest level in over four years.
item.dc:creator: Paul Vieira

item.title: EU Exports to U.S. Drop Sharply
item.description: Goods exported from the EU to the U.S. fell in August following the new tariff agreement and imports also declined, suggesting the trade environment is weakening.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: A reduction in the tariffs faced by Indian businesses exporting to the U.S. would likely boost growth this year, Reserve Bank of India Gov. Sanjay Malhotra said
item.description: Sanjay Malhotra said talks are under way to lower tariffs, and success would help lift the economy.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Upset over higher food prices, consumers are cutting back on purchases, stockpiling certain items or exploring more-affordable stores
item.description: Record beef prices and coffee that costs $1 more per pound since May have shoppers cutting back on some foods, stockpiling others.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Kuo

item.title: China’s Rare-Earth Export Controls Are ‘Critical Concern’ for EU, Trade Chief Says
item.description: Maros Sefcovic said the measures were causing a lot of problems for European companies, as tensions continue to rise between Brussels and Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Edith Hancock

item.title: U.K. Unemployment Edges Higher
item.description: The labor market loosened a little in the three months through August, with unemployment creeping up and wage growth slowing, as firms continued to hold back from hiring.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: The man who won a record Powerball jackpot has a new goal: redevelop his hometown after the L.A. fires
item.description: Edwin Castro is one of the biggest investors snapping up destroyed properties—and he wants to lead in rebuilding his hometown of Altadena.
item.dc:creator: Konrad Putzier

item.title: A California new law to make it easier for developers to build multistory apartment buildings near major commuter stops, has triggered fierce opposition from Los Angeles and other coastal cities
item.description: Gov. Newsom Friday signed a bill that will make it easier to build apartment buildings. Cities like Los Angeles fear a loss of control.
item.dc:creator: Paul Kiernan

item.title: Consumer Sentiment Holds Steady in October
item.description: Economic sentiment remained grim but held steady near recent levels in October as a federal shutdown hampered government functions and sidelined thousands of workers, according to the University of Michigan’s latest consumer survey.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: IMF Chief Sees Global Growth Slowing ‘Only Slightly’ in Face of Higher Tariffs
item.description: The global economy is holding up better than expected in the face of higher tariffs and greater uncertainty about relations between powerful countries and the implications of technological change, the head of the International Monetary Fund said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: A host of alternative jobs data from Wall Street are pointing in the same direction: The U.S. labor market is losing steam
item.description: In a federal data blackout, Wall Street numbers and surveys are filling the void, and the nongovernment numbers are telling the same basic story: Few companies are hiring.
item.dc:creator: Konrad Putzier

item.title: Federal-Worker Buyouts Are Kicking In, Darkening the U.S. Employment Picture
item.description: About 100,000 federal workers came off the payroll last week, adding strain to an already weakening labor market.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Louise Ensign

item.title: Unboxing the thrill of Labubus, or why so many young consumers are spending big on blind boxes
item.description: Getting hold of Labubus and other blind-box toys is a game of odds; the thrill of the surprise keeps young consumers coming back for more.
item.dc:creator: Audrey Valbuena

item.title: Eurozone Inflation Picks Up Pace as ECB Looks Set to Keep Rates on Hold
item.description: European Central Bank rate setters are sanguine about potential pressures on prices and expect last month’s rise in inflation to be short-lived.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: BOE Deputy Governor Sees Inflation Resuming Fall After ‘Hump’
item.description: The recent pickup in inflation, which is projected to hit 4% this month before declining, is unlikely to have long-lasting consequences, said Sarah Breeden.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Census Bureau data show that average U.S. households haven’t gained ground economically since the Covid-19 pandemic struck
item.description: High-income households fared better than others, while women lost ground to men, according to Census Bureau data.
item.dc:creator: Konrad Putzier
